Package org.jtrim2.collections

Class CollectionsEx

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.collections.CollectionsEx
public final class CollectionsEx extends Object
Contains helper methods for arrays not present in Collections.

This class cannot be instantiated or inherited.

  • Method Details

    • newMap

      public static <K, V> Map<K,V> newMap(Class<K> keyType, Consumer<? super Map<K,V>> contentConfig)
      Creates and populates a Map. This method is a convenience to create a non-empty map without requiring explicit declaration. It is useful when passing a map as an argument or when initializing a (static) field. For example: 
      
 static final Map<MyKey, String> MY_MAP = CollectionsEx.newMap(MyKey.class, map -> {
   map.put(MyKey.KEY1, "Value1");
   map.put(MyKey.KEY2, "Value2");
 });
      The type of the map to be created depends on the type of the key. If the key is an enum, an EnumMap is created, otherwise a HashMap.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the created map
      V - the type of the value of the created map
      Parameters:
      keyType - the type of the key of the created map. This argument cannot be null.
      contentConfig - the lambda to which the map to be returned is passed. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the newly created map, after initialized by the given lambda. This method never returns null.

    • newEnumMap

      public static <K extends Enum<K>, V> EnumMap<K,V> newEnumMap(Class<K> keyType, Consumer<? super EnumMap<K,V>> contentConfig)
      Creates and populates a EnumMap. This method is a convenience to create a non-empty map without requiring explicit declaration. It is useful when passing a map as an argument or when initializing a (static) field. For example: 
      
 static final Map<MyEnum, String> MY_MAP = CollectionsEx.newEnumMap(MyEnum.class, map -> {
   map.put(MyEnum.KEY1, "Value1");
   map.put(MyEnum.KEY2, "Value2");
 });
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the created map
      V - the type of the value of the created map
      Parameters:
      keyType - the type of the key of the created map. This argument cannot be null.
      contentConfig - the lambda to which the map to be returned is passed. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the newly created map, after initialized by the given lambda. This method never returns null.

    • newHashMap

      public static <K, V> HashMap<K,V> newHashMap(Consumer<? super HashMap<K,V>> contentConfig)
      Creates and populates a HashMap. This method is a convenience to create a non-empty map without requiring explicit declaration. It is useful when passing a map as an argument or when initializing a (static) field. For example: 
      
 static final Map<String, String> MY_MAP = CollectionsEx.newHashMap(map -> {
   map.put("Key1", "Value1");
   map.put("Key2", "Value2");
 });
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the created map
      V - the type of the value of the created map
      Parameters:
      contentConfig - the lambda to which the map to be returned is passed. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the newly created map, after initialized by the given lambda. This method never returns null.

    • newLinkedHashMap

      public static <K, V> LinkedHashMap<K,V> newLinkedHashMap(int expectedSize)
      Creates a new LinkedHashMap specifying the expected number of mappings. The returned map will never do a rehash if the number of mappings remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of mappings the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the returned map
      V - the type of the value of the returned map
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected number mappings. This argument must not be a negative value.
      Returns:
      a hash map with a loadFactor == 0.75 and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative

    • newLinkedHashMap

      public static <K, V> LinkedHashMap<K,V> newLinkedHashMap(int expectedSize, float loadFactor)
      Creates a new LinkedHashMap specifying the expected number of mappings and the load factor. The returned map will never do a rehash if the number of mappings remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of mappings the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the returned map
      V - the type of the value of the returned map
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected number mappings. This argument must not be a negative value.
      loadFactor - the load factor of the returned hash map. This argument must be a positive value
      Returns:
      a hash map with the specified load factor and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative or the loadFactor is nonpositive

    • newHashMap

      public static <K, V> HashMap<K,V> newHashMap(int expectedSize)
      Creates a new HashMap specifying the expected number of mappings. The returned map will never do a rehash if the number of mappings remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of mappings the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the returned map
      V - the type of the value of the returned map
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected number mappings. This argument must not be a negative value.
      Returns:
      a hash map with a loadFactor == 0.75 and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative

    • newHashMap

      public static <K, V> HashMap<K,V> newHashMap(int expectedSize, float loadFactor)
      Creates a new HashMap specifying the expected number of mappings and the load factor. The returned map will never do a rehash if the number of mappings remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of mappings the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the key of the returned map
      V - the type of the value of the returned map
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected number mappings. This argument must not be a negative value.
      loadFactor - the load factor of the returned hash map. This argument must be a positive value
      Returns:
      a hash map with the specified load factor and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative or the loadFactor is nonpositive

    • newLinkedHashSet

      public static <E> LinkedHashSet<E> newLinkedHashSet(int expectedSize)
      Creates a new LinkedHashSet specifying the expected number of elements. The returned set will never do a rehash if the number of elements remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of elements the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the values of the returned set
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected number elements. This argument must not be a negative value.
      Returns:
      a hash set with a loadFactor == 0.75 and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative

    • newLinkedHashSet

      public static <E> LinkedHashSet<E> newLinkedHashSet(int expectedSize, float loadFactor)
      Creates a new LinkedHashSet specifying the expected number of elements and the load factor. The returned set will never do a rehash if the number of elements remain bellow the specified size. So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of elements the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the values of the returned set
      Parameters:

      loadFactor - the load factor of the returned hash set. This argument must be a positive value
      Returns:
      a hash set with the specified load factor and a minimal capacity which is enough to store the specified number of elements without a rehash. This method always returns a new unique object.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the expectedSize is negative or the loadFactor is nonpositive

      public static <E> HashSet<E> newHashSet(int expectedSize, float loadFactor)

So if a reasonable upper bound can be specified for the number of elements the expensive rehash operation can be avoided.

    • newIdentityHashSet

      public static <E> Set<E> newIdentityHashSet(int expectedSize)
      Returns a new set which is based on the reference equality operator (==) instead of its equals method. This method is equivalent to Collections.newSetFromMap(new IdentityHashMap<E, Boolean>(expectedSize)). Note that this method does not return a general purpose set implementation because it does not rely on the equals method of its elements.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the elements of the set
      Parameters:
      expectedSize - the expected size the returned set. The returned set will not execute a time consuming rehash operation if its size will not grow over this limit.
      Returns:
      the newly returned

    • readOnlyCopy

      public static <E> List<E> readOnlyCopy(Collection<? extends E> c)
      Returns an unmodifiable copy of the specified collection. The returned list is always a random access list and will contain the elements in the order the iterator of the specified collection returned them.

      The result of this method is undefined if the specified collection is modified while calling this method.

      Note that this method does not necessarily returns a unique object each time, only ensures that the returned list will be independent of the specified collection (except that it will contain the same objects) so subsequent modifications to the specified collection will not be reflected in the returned list.

      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the elements of the specified collection
      Parameters:
      c - the collection which is to be copied. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the readonly copy of the specified collection. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified collection is null

    • viewConcatList

      public static <E> List<E> viewConcatList(List<? extends E> list1, List<? extends E> list2)
      Returns a readonly view of two concatenated lists. Changes made to the specified lists will be reflected immediately in the returned list.

      The returned list will contain the elements in the order they are contained in the specified lists; the elements of the first list coming first.

      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the elements in the list
      Parameters:
      list1 - the first part of the concatenated list. This argument cannot be null.
      list2 - the second part of the concatenated list. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the concatenated view of the specified lists. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null

    • viewListWithHead

      public static <E> List<E> viewListWithHead(E head, List<? extends E> list2)
      Returns a readonly view of the given list with the given head element as the head of the new list. That is, the returned list will have exactly one element more than the given source list.

      Calling this method is effectively equivalent to calling: viewConcatList(Collections.singletonList(head), list2)

      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the elements in the list
      Parameters:
      head - the first element of the returned list. This argument can be null, in which case the returned list will have null as its first element.
      list2 - the second part of the concatenated list. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a readonly view of the given list with the given head element. This mehtod never returns null.

    • viewListWithTail

      public static <E> List<E> viewListWithTail(List<? extends E> list1, E tail)
      Returns a readonly view of the given list with the given tail element as the tail of the new list. That is, the returned list will have exactly one element more than the given source list.

      Calling this method is effectively equivalent to calling: viewConcatList(list1, Collections.singletonList(tail))

      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of the elements in the list
      Parameters:
      list1 - the first part of the concatenated list. This argument cannot be null.
      tail - the last element of the returned list. This argument can be null, in which case the returned list will have null as its last element.
      Returns:
      a readonly view of the given list with the given tail element. This mehtod never returns null.

    • naturalOrder

      public static <T> Comparator<T> naturalOrder()
      Returns a comparator which uses the natural ordering of elements. Note that the returned comparator can only be used on elements implementing the Comparator interface.

      Note that the return comparator is not entirely type safe and must not be abused otherwise unexpected ClassCastException can be thrown while trying to use it.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements which the returned comparator compares
      Returns:
      a comparator which uses the natural ordering of elements. This method never returns null.

    • getDetachedListRef

      public static <E> RefList.ElementRef<E> getDetachedListRef(E element)
      Returns an element reference of a list which is not actually attached to any list. The returned element reference will be a detached reference containing the specified element.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of element
      Parameters:
      element - the element contained in the returned list element reference. This argument will be returned by RefCollection.ElementRef.getElement().
      Returns:
      a detached list element reference of the specified element. This method never returns null.

    • copyToEnumMap

      public static <K extends Enum<K>, V> EnumMap<K,V> copyToEnumMap(Class<K> keyType, Map<? extends K,? extends V> src)
      Returns a copy of the given map where the key is an enum.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the keys
      V - the type of the values
      Parameters:
      keyType - the type of the keys. This argument cannot be null.
      src - the map to be copied. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null keys. However, null values are permitted.
      Returns:
      the copy of the given map. This method never returns null.

    • copyToReadOnlyEnumMap

      public static <K extends Enum<K>, V> Map<K,V> copyToReadOnlyEnumMap(Class<K> keyType, Map<? extends K,? extends V> src)
      Returns a read-only copy of the given map where the key is an enum. The returned map is backed by an EnumMap.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of the keys
      V - the type of the values
      Parameters:
      keyType - the type of the keys. This argument cannot be null.
      src - the map to be copied. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null keys. However, null values are permitted.
      Returns:
      the read-only copy of the given map. This method never returns null.
